Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mathematical, Computational and Experimental Modeling of the Multidisciplinary Dynamics of Fluid-Structure Interaction

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective and Intellectual Merits: In an age where multidisciplinary interactions have become ubiquitous in science and engineering, the interaction of a flowing fluid and a deformable structure or solid is one of the richest sources of mathematical challenges and fundamental physical phenomena with important applications to engineering and technology. Examples of mathematical challenges are the chaotic, high dimensional modeling of turbulence that continues to defy rationale predictions from first principles to the many distinct and complex limit cycle oscillations that emerge from dynamic stabilities that arise due to fluid-structure interaction. The physical phenomena of interest range from blood flows in arteries, to airflow over an oscillating tongue that can lead to clinical dangerous and potentially fatal oscillations, to flow over flexible long span bridges and tall buildings, to flow over and around flight vehicles over a wide range of scales from micro air vehicles to modern passenger airliners, to fluid-structural systems whose limit cycles may be a source of energy harvesting.

The methods that have been proposed to better understand and exploit these phenomena include theoretical models of high sophistication including the continuum models of the fluid and the structure. While analytical solutions continue to be sought and found, computational models that tax the resources of the most powerful computers also play an important role as do scale model experiments based upon a sound fundamental analysis and understanding of the first principles of the relevant continuum models. Indeed it is by exploiting the complementary strengths of each approach, theoretical modeling, computational modeling and experimental scale models that the deepest and richest insights can be obtained.

Such a collaborative approach is proposed here. Professor Balakrishnan will lead the theoretical modeling effort, Professor Hodges will be primarily responsible for the computational models and Professor Dowell will be the lead for the experimental scale model effort. Taken together this will be a powerful and highly experienced team It is expected that each investigator and the members of their research teams will learn much about the multidisciplinary dynamics of fluid-structure interaction, and also from each other!

There are many physical phenomena that might be chosen to focus our research program. Based upon our experience and after consultation among the principals, two have been chosen for this research project, i.e. long span wing-like structures in a flowing fluid which are found in novel flight vehicle designs and long span bridges and flapping ?flags? which are studies as models of the human tongue and also have been proposed as energy harvesting devices from the natural wind.

Broader Impact: This proposal brings together senior investigators from three major research institutions covering a wide range of intellectual experience from modern mathematics to rigorously based computational models to multidisciplinary experiments to address fluid-structure interaction phenomena. This research will also provide an opportunity for graduate students and post-doctoral visitors to participate and learn in this rich environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaborative research effort between senior researchers at UCLA, Duke, and Georgia Tech to study Fluid Structure Interaction (FSI) in flexible structures subject to axial flow. In the case of normal flow systems, such as aircraft wings, bridges, and tall buildings, aeroelastic flutter is usually undesirable and can often lead to catastrophic failure. In contrast, the axial flow system considered in this project, a low wind speed energy harvester, serves a useful purpose as a result of being subjected to flutter. With the use of piezoelectric materials, a beam-like structure fluttering in the wind, much in the way that a flag does, can output useable electrical energy.

The primary goals of this project were to develop and implement experimental methods to provide more scientific insight into the physical mechanism of axial flutter, and to support key findings of the NSF-supported theoretical research at UCLA. More specifically, the three major objectives and outcomes were:

Objective 1. Design and run accurate and repeatable experiments to determine en-vacuo bending and torsion modes for beams to be used as piezoelectric energy harvesters.

Outcome: Using an automated impact hammer and adjustable mounting system on an optical table, the mode testing apparatus can excite up to three bending and three torsion modes in the structure. This method proved to be very accurate, when compared to beam theory for homogeneous structures, and it allows for the measurement of the structural mode frequencies of nonhomogeneous structures (such as the energy harvester). Figure 1 shows the experimental apparatus (left) and a sample of the frequency domain results (right).

Objective 2. Design and run experiments to determine the flutter speed of the beam structure in a low speed wind tunnel.

Outcome: The flutter speed is accurately measured by placing the structure in the wind tunnel and slowly increasing the air speed until the structure becomes unstable. These experiments serve as a tool to validate theoretical predictions and to explore the feasibility of new energy harvester designs. Figure 2 shows the wind tunnel at UCLA (left) and the wind tunnel test section (right) with the structure mounted in the axial position.

Objective 3. Use high speed cameras to record the beam’s motion after the flutter speed is reached, and observe the characteristics of the Limit Cycle Oscillation (LCO).

Outcome: High speed cameras were used to record the beam’s motion from the top and side views simultaneously while the beam was undergoing unstable LCO motion in the wind tunnel. The resulting footage can be used to quickly determine which modes are unstable for a given air speed, which is important for investigating its energy harvesting capability. To illustrate this concept, first consider the theoretical bending mode shapes as shown in Figure 3.

To determine which of these mode shapes are present during flutter, we can inspect the footage from the top view camera. Figure 4 shows a sequence of frames from the top view camera footage, spanning one oscillation, where the red dots have been superimposed on the image to outline the beam.

Here it is apparent, by comparison to the theoretical mode shapes, that the second bending mode is the dominant mode in the oscillation. Image processing techniques were then implemented to determine the frequencies present in the oscillation, and to determine the beam deflection as a function of time. The image processing Matlab program developed at UCLA is based on producing a binary image for each frame, separating the beam from the background, and tracking the pixels corresponding to the beam to determine its position at each point in time. Figure 5 shows a sample of the image processing results, where the plot on the left is the deflection of the beam’s midplane, and the plot on the right is a frequency domain plot revealing the frequency of the oscillation.

In summary, all three objectives were completed successfully and the resulting outcomes will continue to be useful in the study of axial flow aeroelasticity at UCLA. Although the project has ended, continuing work will include making more air pressure measurements and calculations in the wind tunnel experiments.
